awd_titl_txt: REU Site: Marine Biodiversity: lessons from molecules, development and behavior
awd_abstract_narration:
This REU Site award to the University of Florida's Whitney Laboratory for Marine Bioscience in St. Augustine, FL will provide research training for 8 students for 10 weeks during the summers of 2016-2020. The program provides undergraduates with a realistic research experience that will inspire student interest in science and motivate their consideration of a basic research career. Through individualized interactions with mentors, students perform full-time lab or field research. Increased independence over the course of the program is emphasized. Research projects typically use marine models to enhance student understanding of basic mechanisms in biology in the context of evolution and species biodiversity. Guided field trips to local marine estuaries, inland fresh water springs, and the Gulf coast introduce varied ecosystems. Weekly research seminars and workshops provide training on the responsible conduct of research, professional communication skills, science literacy, and diverse career paths in science related fields. Students meet with graduate coordinators at the University of Florida to learn the graduate school application process. Students are recruited nationwide through digital and flyer-based advertising, at conferences, and trips to institutions. Students are selected based on academic record and research potential. Special attention is given to applicants from groups currently underrepresented in the sciences and groups for whom evidence suggests the REU experience has the greatest impact. 

It is anticipated that a total of 40 students, primarily from schools with limited research opportunities, will be trained in the program. Students will learn how research is conducted, and many will present the results of their work at scientific conferences and pursue advanced STEM training.

A web-based assessment tool used by all REU programs funded by the Division of Biological Infrastructure (Directorate for Biological Sciences) will determine the effectiveness of the training program. Students are tracked after the program to determine their continued interest in science and their career paths. Students will be asked to respond to an automatic email sent via the NSF reporting system. More information is available by visiting http:// http://www.whitney.ufl.edu/academic/undergrad-reu/. Alternatively, contact the PI Dr. Elaine Seaver (seaver@whitney.ufl.edu) or the Whitney Education Coordinator, Brenda Cannaliato (Brenda@whitney.ufl.edu).

por.por_cntn:
The Undergraduate Research Training Program in Marine Bioscience at University of Florida’s Whitney Laboratory (2016-2024) had two major aims: (1)  to immerse undergraduate students in an authentic, professional research environment that reinforced their interest in research, potentially motivating them to consider research as a career option in the process, and (2) to make students aware of the value of marine animals in fundamental biological biological research. We sought to train students for whom the REU experience has been shown to have the greatest impact: students from four year colleges with limited access to research training, students with no prior research training, and students from groups currently underrepresented in the sciences. We trained 43 students during this grant period. We accepted students in 6 of the 8 years, between 2016-2024, when this grant was active (2020 and 2022 were postponed due to concerns surrounding the pandemic).

Each student worked on a different project that contributed to the larger research effort of the laboratory in which they were mentored, and weaving them into the overall research effort of the wider Whitney community. Specifically, the Whitney laboratory is comprised of eleven research groups, with research interests in marine biology, chemistry, neuroscience, aquaculture, and coastal development. We offer state-of-the-art techniques and equipment for student training from single-cell sequencing, gene editing, optogenetics, evolutionary phylogeny, using confocal and custom build microscopes, mass spectrometers, and animal tracking technology. Students were provided hands-on training in advanced techniques in one or more of the following areas: cell biology, molecular biology, developmental biology, biochemistry, natural products research, neurobiology, genomics, and evolutionary biology. All student research involved marine organisms most often in a comparative framework for understanding basic questions in biology. Many interdiciplinary projects were offered, for example connecting the animal physiology with micrbiomes or chemicals present. Students received weekly training in scientific communication and research ethics in addition to conducting research. Students also visited with coordinators of different graduate programs on the University of Florida’s main campus to gain insight into how to successfully navigate the graduate school application process. Finally, our program included several community-building activities including picnics and field trips into Florida’s diverse marine, estuarine and freshwater environments. All Whitney student mentors attended a mentoring workshop before and during the summer program to hone in their teaching skills and discuss challenges and opportunities.

At the end of the 10-week program, each student produced a poster and gave an oral presentation in which they described their work. Almost half of our students presented their research at national conferences, 14 earned co-authorship of peer-reviewed publications including six first-author publications. Several additional publications co-authored by undergraduate trainees are currently in preparation. 

Since 1987, the Whitney Lab has consistently conducted a highly successful REU program, underscoring its enduring dedication to furnishing undergraduates with top-tier research training opportunities. We maintain a database of our 345 Whitney Lab REU alumni and we reach out to these former students periodically to check on how they are doing and what they are up to. Over the course of this REU grant, we hosted 5 Whitney Lab REU alumni to give seminars and to interact with our current students. These included talks from two university faculty, a patent lawyer, a Ph.D. AAAS Science & Technology Policy fellow, and a senior graduate student. Assessment of the NSF REU program has been a high priorty and we used annual survey’s to inform the next years offering and to assess the impact on their prececption of basic science, marine research, and STEM careers. We continue to stay in contact with our alumni and are happy to report that many of the alumni from this current grant have continued with research careers including a large number who have gone on to graduate school at some of the most prestigious universities in the world.
